{{Use Australian English|date=August 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox school | name = Adelaide Central School of Art | established = 1982 | city = [[Adelaide]] | state = [[South Australia|SA]] | country = Australia | website = [http://www.acsa.sa.edu.au/ www.acsa.sa.edu.au] | logo = Adelaide Central School of Art Logo.png }}
'''Adelaide Central School of Art''' is an independent, not-for-profit, accredited higher education provider of tertiary courses in the [[visual arts]], located in [[Adelaide]], Australia<ref name="TEQSA">{{cite web |title=Adelaide Central School of Art Incorporated |url=https://www.teqsa.gov.au/national-register/provider/adelaide-central-school-art-incorporated |website=www.teqsa.gov.au |publisher=Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency |accessdate=20 August 2018 |language=en |date=3 November 2017}}</ref>. Adelaide Central School of Art uses the [[atelier]] model of visual arts education.<ref>{{cite news |title=The art of the matter |work=The Advertiser (Adelaide) |date=1 September 2001}}</ref> The school offers an associate degree of Visual Art, Bachelor of Visual Art, and Bachelor of Visual Art (Hons), and short courses, workshops and masterclasses.<ref name=acsa>{{cite web|title=Adelaide Central School of Art: Home|url=http://www.acsa.sa.edu.au/home/|publisher=acsa.sa.edu.au|accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=adelaidenow>{{cite web|last=Nunn|first=Louise|title=Adelaide Central School of Art now at Glenside|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/art-school-drawn-to-a-new-address-at-glenside/story-e6frea6u-1226305667524|publisher=adelaidenow.com.au|accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=yelp>{{cite web|title=Adelaide Central School of Art|url=http://www.yelp.com.au/biz/adelaide-central-school-of-art-glenside|publisher=yelp.com.au|accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=directionsmagazine>{{cite web|title=SCHOOL OF THE FUTURE: ADELAIDE CENTRAL SCHOOL OF ARTS |url=http://www.directionsmagazine.com.au/Story/AdelaideCentralSchoolOfArts |publisher=directionsmagazine.com.au |accessdate=13 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222184631/http://www.directionsmagazine.com.au/Story/AdelaideCentralSchoolOfArts |archivedate=22 February 2014 }}</ref>
==History== The School was founded in 1982 by Rod Taylor and Heather Nicholson<ref>{{cite book |last1=Gordon |first1=Maureen |title=Adelaide Central School of Art: A short history |date=2004 |publisher=Gordon and Tippett |location=Adelaide, SA |isbn=097570320X |page=5}}</ref>. Initially occupying a rented space in Bloor Court, Adelaide, it moved in 1988 to a warehouse in Gilles Street, establishing itself as an accredited independent art school<ref>{{cite book |last1=Gordon |first1=Maureen |title=Adelaide Central School of Art: A short history |date=2004 |publisher=Gordon and Tippett |location=Adelaide, SA |isbn=097570320X |page=6}}</ref>. In January 1994, the School moved to heritage buildings in Osmond Terrace, Norwood, leasing them from the School's founder until they were sold in 2011. Taylor retired in 2008 and was succeeded by Ingrid Kellenbach as CEO<ref>{{cite web |last1=Nunn |first1=Louise |title=School's out for man of vision |url=http://web.a.ebscohost.com.rp.nla.gov.au/ehost/detail/detail?vid=0&sid=88396923-c076-476e-991e-d572dfbe8d7b%40sessionmgr4010&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWhvc3QtbGl2ZQ%3d%3d#AN=200809101027855324&db=anh |publisher=The Advertiser (Adelaide) |accessdate=20 August 2018 |date=10 September 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=New art school chief |url=http://web.a.ebscohost.com.rp.nla.gov.au/ehost/detail/detail?vid=0&sid=6530bbd7-9ab6-4358-b92b-335f789f1978%40sessionmgr4008&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWhvc3QtbGl2ZQ%3d%3d#AN=200810301015030668&db=anh |publisher=The Advertiser (Adelaide) |accessdate=20 August 2018 |date=30 October 2008}}</ref>. Adelaide Central School of Art relocated to the Glenside Cultural Precinct in January 2013, completing the first stage of the renovation of two iconic heritage buildings in May 2013<ref>{{cite web |last1=Altschwager |first1=Emma |title=School of Art flourishing |url=http://web.a.ebscohost.com.rp.nla.gov.au/ehost/detail/detail?vid=0&sid=7843e013-2833-4b4d-adfe-5a828513b4ee%40sessionmgr4006&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWhvc3QtbGl2ZQ%3d%3d#AN=201301301017495318&db=anh |publisher=Eastern Courier (Adelaide) |accessdate=20 August 2018 |date=30 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Nunn |first1=Louise |title=Adelaide Central School of Art now at Glenside |url=https://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/art-school-drawn-to-a-new-address-at-glenside/story-e6frea6u-1226305667524 |publisher=The Advertiser (Adelaide) |accessdate=20 August 2018 |date=21 March 2012}}</ref>. The South Australian Government granted the School a 50-year lease on these buildings located adjacent to the Adelaide Film Studios home of the South Australian Film Corporation and related creative enterprises. The new Glenside Campus provides facilities in the three-story Teaching and Studio Building, including spaces for classes, integrated student studios, lecture room, media room, enlarged library facilities and display space for artwork on each level.
In September 2018, the School announced that Penny Griggs, Director of the [[SALA Festival]], would succeed Ingrid Kellenbach as the School's CEO in November 2018.<ref>{{cite web |last1=McDonald |first1=Patrick |title=SALA Festival boss Penny Griggs to succeed Ingrid Kellenbach at Adelaide Central School of Art |url=https://www.adelaidenow.com.au/national/south-australia/sala-festival-boss-penny-griggs-to-succeed-ingrid-kellenbach-at-adelaide-central-school-of-art/news-story/84ffffb77d3db90c5d35ca7dffbd5c3c |website=The Advertiser (Adelaide) |accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref>
==Degree courses == The degree courses are designed to develop technical and conceptual skills. The curriculum includes the disciplines of drawing, painting, sculpture, art history and theory and contemporary studies, for part-time or full-time study.
==Campus == The School is located on the [[Glenside, South Australia|Glenside]] campus in two heritage buildings that formed part of the [[Glenside Hospital (Adelaide)|Glenside Hospital]]. The buildings were renovated by Adelaide-based architects Grieve Gillett in consultation with the School and the renovation received an award from the Australian Institute of Architects for Heritage Architecture in 2014<ref>{{cite web |title=2014 SA Architecture Awards |url=https://architectureau.com/articles/2014-sa-architecture-awards/ |website=ArchitectureAU |accessdate=20 August 2018 |language=en-AU}}</ref>.
[[File:Adelaide Central School of Art Teaching and Studio Building.jpg|thumb|Teaching and Studio Building, Adelaide Central School of Art. Formerly the P&O Building (men's ward), Glenside Hospital]]
==Adelaide Central Gallery ==
The Adelaide Central Gallery was formally opened as part of the School in 1991. At threat of closure in 2002,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Nunn |first1=Louise |title=School gallery closes |work=The Advertiser (Adelaide) |date=19 June 2002 |page=68}}</ref> a restructure in 2003 allowed the gallery to continue.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Nunn |first1=Louise |title=Gallery gets a new lease on life |work=The Advertiser (Adelaide). |date=28 April 2003 |page=77}}</ref> The gallery has hosted two award-winning exhibitions: Façade received the 2018 [[Adelaide Fringe Festival]]/[[BankSA]] Award for Best Visual Art & Design;<ref>{{cite web |title=2018 BankSA Fringe Award Winners {{!}} Adelaide Fringe - 15 February - 17 March 2019 |url=https://adelaidefringe.com.au/2018-fringe-award-winners |website=adelaidefringe.com.au |accessdate=29 October 2018 |language=en}}</ref> and Home Stories received the 2011 [[Adelaide Fringe Festival]] Eran Svigos Award for Best Visual Art & Design.<ref>{{cite web |title=Adelaide Fringe - ADELAIDE FRINGE AWARDS |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110403073018/http://www.adelaidefringe.com.au/Media/News-Latest/ADELAIDE-FRINGE-AWARDS.aspx |accessdate=29 October 2018 |date=3 April 2011}}</ref>
==Rankings==
In the Quality Indicators for Learning and Teaching survey for 2017, the school was ranked the best art school in Australia for 2017 (second-best in 2016)<ref>{{cite web |author1=Quality Indicators for Learning and Teaching |title=Adelaide Central School of Art |url=https://www.qilt.edu.au/institutions/list/institution/adelaide-central-school-of-art |website=www.qilt.edu.au |publisher=Social Research Centre |accessdate=24 August 2018 |language=en}}</ref>.

{{Infobox royalty | name = Princess Adélaïde | title = Madame Adélaïde | image = Adélaide d'Orléans.jpg | full name = Louise Marie Adelaïde Eugénie d'Orléans. | birth_date = {{birth date|1777|8|23|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Palais Royal]], [[Paris]], France | death_date = {{death date and age|1847|12|31|1777|8|23|df=y}} | death_place = [[Palais des Tuileries]], Paris, France | burial_place = [[Chapelle royale de Dreux|Royal Chapel]], [[Dreux]] | house = [[House of Orléans|Orléans]] | father = ''[[Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans|Philippe Égalité]]'' | mother = [[Louise Marie Adélaïde de Bourbon]] | religion = [[Roman Catholicism]] }} [[File:Princesse Louise Marie Eugénie Adélaïde-d’Orléans-PansiesMorningGloriesandSingleChrysanthemums00.jpg|thumb|<center>1812 painting by Adélaïde</center>]] [[File:Princesse Louise Marie Eugénie Adélaïde-d’Orléans01.jpg|thumb|<center>Summer posy by Adélaïde</center>]] '''Louise Marie ''Adélaïde'' Eugénie d'Orléans''' ([[Paris]], 23 August 1777 – Paris, 31 December 1847) was a French princess, one of the [[twin]] daughters of [[Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans|Philippe d'Orléans]], known as ''Philippe Égalité'' during the [[French Revolution]], and [[Louise Marie Adélaïde de Bourbon]]. She was titled ''Mademoiselle de Chartres'' at birth, ''Mademoiselle d'Orléans'' at the death of her twin sister in 1782, ''Mademoiselle'' (1783–1812), ''Madame Adélaïde'' (1830). As a member of the reigning [[House of Bourbon]], she was a ''[[Prince du Sang|princesse du sang]]''.
== Biography == Adélaïde was raised according to the liberal principles of her governess, [[Stéphanie Félicité du Crest de Saint-Aubin|Madame de Genlis]], principles which also became her own political conviction. She received an excellent but also very hard and strenuous education; to harden herself, she learned to sleep on a hard bed and arise at six every day. She was deeply attached to her governess, and her mother's demand that de Genlis be replaced, though without success, was reportedly a cause of great worry for her. She was considered for marriage to the [[Louis Antoine, Duke of Angoulême|Duke of Angoulême]], but the plans were prevented by queen [[Marie Antoinette]]. Later on, she was also considered for marriage to the [[Charles Ferdinand, Duke of Berry|Duke of Berry]], which did not materialise either.
During the [[French Revolution]], de Genlis on at least one occasion took her to the radical [[Cordelieres Club]]. In 1791, her father asked de Genlis to take her to [[England]] for her safety. The year after, he summoned them back to prevent Adelaide's name from being placed on the list of emigrees. When they arrived, however, de Genlis discovered that Adélaïde was already on the list and that her father, whose political situation had deteriorated, asked her to take Adélaïde out of the country again.
Adelaide received painting lessons from [[Pierre-Joseph Redouté]] and produced some highly-regarded botanical studies as a result. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.johnmitchell.net/Princesse-Louise-Marie-Eugenie-Adelaide-dOrleans-1777-1847-Pansies-Morning-Glories-and-Single-Chrysanthemums-DesktopDefault.aspx?tabid=6&tabindex=5&objectid=668553&categoryid=10236|title=Pansies, Morning Glories and Single Chrysanthemums|publisher=}}</ref>
===Life in exile=== In 1792, she left France with de Genlis to the [[Austrian Netherlands]] and then to [[Switzerland]], where she was placed in a convent in Bremgarten. During the Terror her father was guillotined, and her mother was banished to [[Spain]]. Sometime in the spring of 1794, Adélaïde moved to the home of her aunt, the [[Maria Fortunata d'Este|Princess of Conti]]. They moved to Bavaria in 1798 and thereafter to [[Bratislava]], and in 1801, she joined her mother in [[Barcelona]] in Spain. Her relationship with her mother was not good, as she disapproved of her mother's relationship with chancellor de Folmont.
On 25 November 1809, she and her mother attended the wedding of her brother [[Louis Philippe I|Louis Philippe]] to [[Maria Amalia of Naples and Sicily]] in [[Palermo, Sicily|Palermo]] on [[Sicily]]. After the wedding, she did not return with her mother to Spain, but preferred to live with her brother and sister-in-law at Palazzo Orléans in Palermo. She was described as completely devoted to her brother and his family: united with her sister-in-law in their mutual love and concern for him, and a second mother to his children.
===Return to France=== After the fall of Napoleon in 1814, she returned with her brother and his family to Paris and settled with them in [[Palais-Royal]]. During the [[Bourbon Restoration]], Palais-Royal was described as a center of high society social life in the capital, and reportedly, despite the fact that custom dictated that she as an unmarried "spinster" was expected to live in the background, it was she rather than her more reserved sister-in-law who took the role of hostess.
She was described as firm, intellectual, and frank, and she was a leading force in the family councils of the [[House of Orléans]]. Her loyalty to her brother has been described as due to the fact that, early separated from her family, she was treated with reserve during her exile because of the political actions of her father during the revolution, and her brother was the first person she could lavish her affection upon. Louis Philippe, in turn, relied upon her intelligence and loyalty, made her his confidant and listened to her advice, and consequently, she came to exert great political influence upon him. Being brought up a liberal, she supported the idea of a constitutional monarchy and a representative government.
She was not on good terms with the reigning Bourbon family; because of their reactionary ideas, and also because the hostility shown by the toward the Orléans line, and to her particularly by [[Marie Thérèse of France]]. Adélaïde rather than her brother are described as the active head of the Orléans fraction, and she had the active desire and ambition to make him monarch. In her apartment at Palais-Royal, she hosted a salon which became the center of liberal opposition toward the regime, and by use of her great personal fortune, she supported the liberal press and various political actors, artists, intellectuals and influential figures to gather support for her brother, among them Talleyrand.
===July Monarchy=== When Louis-Philippe became King of the French in the reign known as the [[July Monarchy]] (1830–1848), she was known as ''Madame Adélaïde''. All her life, she was his loyal advisor or, in 19th century parlance, his "[[Egeria (mythology)|Egeria]]". It was she who, reportedly, encouraged him to accept the crown during the [[July revolution]], and her influence continued undisturbed during his reign. When tumult followed the publication of the Ordinances in 1830 and erupted in the July revolution in Paris, the Orléans family was at the country estate Neuilly.
Adélaïde convinced Louis-Philippe that the moment was right for him to place himself as the leader of the opposition against the [[Absolute monarchy in France|absolute monarchy]] of [[Charles X of France|Charles X]], and present himself as the candidate of a [[constitutional monarchy]], in between the unpopular absolute monarchy and the republicanism.<ref name="auto">Dyson, C. C: The life of Marie Amélie last queen of the French, 1782–1866. With some account of the principal personages at the courts of Naples and France in her time, and of the careers of her sons and daughters (1910).</ref> In this, she defeated the view of her sister-in-law Maria Amalia, who was loyal to the reigning older branch. When rumors arrived that the royalists were going to arrest Louis-Philippe, he evacuated to [[Raincy]] and the children were sent to Villiers-Coterets, but Adélaïde and Maria Amalia remained at Neuilly. When a delegation reached Neuilly and offered Louis-Philippe the crown, Maria Amalia refused the offer on behalf of herself and her spouse as an insult, reproaching Scheffer and [[Adolphe Thiers|Thiers]] for insulting them by having made it.<ref name="auto"/> Adélaïde, however, accepted it with the argument that her brother would do anything to prevent the country he loved from anarchy.<ref name="auto"/> Thiers accepted the answer of Adélaïde rather than the one from Maria Amalia with the words: "Madame, you have given the crown to your family".<ref name="auto"/> After this, several other visits followed from people asking Louis-Philippe to accept the crown: to all, Maria Amalia answered that Louis-Philippe was an honest man and thus could not do it, while Adélaïde contradicted her by stating, that the offer should be made to Louis-Philippe by the chamber of deputies; and if he should hesitate, she would herself go to Paris and accept the crown for him.<ref name="auto"/> Soon after, the Chamber of Deputies called Louis-Philippe to Paris to formally present him their offer. It has been estimated that he accepted the crown largely because of Adélaïde.<ref name="auto"/>
At 6 August 1830, she and her sister-in-law were present at the tribune on the ceremony at the chambers in Paris when Louis Philippe was declared King of the French. She and her sister-in-law visited those who had been wounded during the revolution, and supported them financially. In October 1830, a mob broke into the Palais-Royal, and repeated attempts were made to execute the ministers of the former regime, which was refused by Louis-Philippe. When marshal [[Étienne Maurice Gérard|Gerard]] remarked that it would be difficult to save them, she replied: "Well Monsieur, then we will all perish in the attempt".<ref name="auto"/> During his reign, Louis-Philippe visited her daily, discussed the matters of state and family with her, and followed her advice.<ref name="auto"/> Her death was therefore regarded as a great loss not only on an emotional but also a political scale.
Adélaïde d'Orléans died on 31 December 1847, two months before Louis Philippe's abdication on 24 February 1848. She is buried in the Orléans family necropolis in the [[Chapelle royale de Dreux|Royal Chapel of Dreux]].

{{Infobox artwork |image_file=Oración en el huerto (Correggio).jpg |title=Agony in the Garden |artist=[[Correggio]] |medium=oil on panel |height_metric=38 |width_metric=41 |museum=[[Apsley House]] |city=London |website={{URL|https://artuk.org/discover/artworks/the-agony-in-the-garden-144127|Art UK entry}} }} '''''Agony in the Garden''''' is a small 1524 oil on panel painting of the [[Agony in the Garden]] by [[Correggio]], now at [[Apsley House]] in [[London]].<ref name="correggioarthome">{{cite web|url=http://www.correggioarthome.it/SchedaOpera.jsp?idDocumentoArchivio=2533#|title=Ricerca avanzata|website=Correggio ART HOME|accessdate=2017-09-28}}</ref><ref name="the-athenaeum">{{cite web|url=http://www.the-athenaeum.org/art/detail.php?ID=37762|title=The Agony in the Garden - Correggio|website=The Athenaeum|accessdate=2017-09-28}}</ref><ref name="artuk">{{cite web|url=https://artuk.org/discover/artworks/the-agony-in-the-garden-144127|title=The Agony in the Garden|website=Art UK|accessdate=2017-09-28}}</ref>
==History== Now in a poor state, the painting was admired by [[Vasari]] in [[Reggio Emilia]] - he described it as: {{quote|a small painting one foot tall, the rarest and most beautiful thing, in which can be seen his small figures and Christ in the garden - the painting is set at night, with the angel appearing and by the light of his splendor illuminating Christ, who is shown so real and so true that it is impossible to imagine him being expressed better. At the foot of the mountain, on level ground, are three sleeping apostles, above whom he shows Christ praying, which gives an impossible strength to the figures; and even more so, in the background, he shows dawn rising and soldiers coming with Judas from one side of the painting: and in such smallness and with such intensity does he show this story, there is no work that is its parallel for patience and hard work.}} This is supported by [[:File:Bernardino Curti, orazione nell'orto, da Correggio.jpg|a contemporary print of the work by Bernardino Curti]] and a 17th-18th century copy now in the [[National Gallery (London)|National Gallery]].<ref name="nationalgallery">{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/after-correggio-the-agony-in-the-garden|title=After Correggio | The Agony in the Garden | NG76|website=National Gallery, London|accessdate=2017-09-28}}</ref>
It was still in Reggio Emilia in the 1580s, in the collection of Rodolfo Signoretti, where it was studied by [[Lelio Orsi]] (who copied from it in ''Christ among the crosses''), [[Titian]], [[Lomazzo]], [[El Greco]] and [[Annibale Carracci]]. A 1582 source reported that "news [of the work had circulated] in Spain and in Rome" and that [[Philip II of Spain]] and [[Alfonso II d'Este]] had both tried in vain to buy it. The Milanese nobleman Pirro Visconti succeeded in buying it around 1587 and brought it to his villa at [[Lainate]] in [[Milan]], where it found favour as part of the deeply religious era of [[St Charles Borromeo]], who kept a copy of it in the room where he died. It was also copied by [[Giulio Campi]] in a painting now in the [[Pinacoteca Ambrosiana]]. From the [[house of Visconti]] it passed to the [[Marquis of Caracena]] before being taken to Spain by the end of the 17th century - there it was admired by [[Anton Raphael Mengs]] before being acquired by the [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Duke of Wellington]] during the [[Peninsular War]].
